TITLE: Omicron Takes a Toll on Businesses, From Airports to Supermarkets
SUMMARY: Surging Covid-19 infections have prompted flight cancellations, store closures and increased overtime work.

TITLE: AT&T, Verizon Refuse FAA Request to Delay 5G Launch
SUMMARY: The cellphone carriers offered a counterproposal that would allow limited 5G deployments to move forward this week.

TITLE: A Booming Startup Market Prompts an Investment Rush
SUMMARY: Early-stage venture capitalists are now investing millions of dollars in companies before they even have a coherent business plan, while a growing number of VCs are saying that we are likely in a bubble.

TITLE: Tesla Reports 87% Growth in Annual Vehicle Deliveries
SUMMARY: The electric-vehicle maker’s expansion comes despite parts shortages and other logistical problems that have hamstrung the auto industry.

TITLE: Can Paper Replace Plastic? A Packaging Giant Is Betting It Can
SUMMARY: Environmental-driven shift is complicated by frequent higher cost of cardboard, and by carbon-footprint calculus. Kalamazoo paper factory is a big test of whether the flood of ESG capital can transform supply chains.

TITLE: Workers Should See Job Gains Even Amid the Latest Covid-19 Wave
SUMMARY: Economists expect the U.S. labor market to strengthen in the months ahead because employers still need a lot more workers.

TITLE: Headaches and Backlogs Loom as Tax Filing Season Nears Again
SUMMARY: The mid-April deadline is returning as the Internal Revenue Service tries to whittle down piles of paperwork.

TITLE: Economy Week Ahead: Eurozone Manufacturing, U.S. Jobs Report
SUMMARY: This week’s economic indicators will feature measures of U.S. and European manufacturing, the U.S. trade deficit and Friday’s much-watched employment report for America.

TITLE: Chairman's Resignation Hands Control of FDIC to Democrats
SUMMARY: Jelena McWilliams’s decision to resign as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. paves the way for Democrats to gain control of the agency’s agenda.

TITLE: 'Yellowstone' Is a Huge Hit That Started With Small-Town Fans
SUMMARY: Paramount Network’s cowboy soap opera caught on in smaller markets before hitting it big in major cities. Now it is the start of an empire.

TITLE: New Covid-19 Pills Carry Risks: What Patients Should Know
SUMMARY: Pfizer’s antiviral treatment can interact with other drugs in dangerous and life-threatening ways, and Merck’s isn’t recommended for pregnant women.

TITLE: Chip Makers Contend for Scarce Talent
SUMMARY: A limited supply of qualified workers poses a challenge as facilities are built around the world to bolster the supply of semiconductors.

TITLE: Pricey Chicken Puts Thighs on Restaurant Menus
SUMMARY: Dark-meat items are traditionally less popular, but restaurants are promoting them as short supplies have driven up the price of breasts and wings.

TITLE: U.S., European Factories See Easing Supply Strains, but Omicron Threatens Setbacks
SUMMARY: Factories in Europe and the U.S. reported a further easing of supply-chain problems at the end of 2021, although the rapid spread of Omicron could worsen shortages of labor and supplies.

TITLE: Economic Forecasting and the Goldberg Variations
SUMMARY: At best, economic predictions for the year ahead can be as outrageously elaborate as a Rube Goldberg contraption—and 2022 could be trickier than usual.

TITLE: Apple Becomes First U.S. Company to Reach $3 Trillion Market Value
SUMMARY: The iPhone maker’s shares passed the milestone when they topped $182.856 a share. The stock is up 38% since the beginning of 2021.

TITLE: Jury in Elizabeth Holmes Trial Deadlocked on Three of 11 Counts
SUMMARY: A federal judge instructed jurors in the criminal-fraud trial of the Theranos founder to continue deliberating after they said they were unable to reach a unanimous verdict on three charges.

TITLE: FDA Authorizes Pfizer-BioNTech Booster for 12- to 15-Year-Olds
SUMMARY: U.S. health regulators cleared use of a Covid-19 booster from Pfizer and BioNTech in adolescents 12 to 15 years old, expanding access to an extra dose that could bolster the fight against the Omicron variant.

TITLE: Tesla Opens Showroom in China's Xinjiang
SUMMARY: The auto maker, widely admired in China, is wading into a region at the center of a human-rights dispute that has entangled Western companies.

TITLE: Covid Brings America's Beer-vs.-Liquor Rivalry to a Head
SUMMARY: Brewers struggle to retain a dwindling edge, as spirits makers campaign to grab market share using canned cocktails to burnish their product’s reputation and lower taxes on it. “Alcohol is alcohol.”

TITLE: Steelmakers Dive Into Junk Business to Feed New Mills
SUMMARY: U.S. steel producers are buying up scrap businesses, seeking a steady supply of raw material from junked cars and manufacturing waste for new mills.

TITLE: AMC Entertainment to Refinance High-Interest Debt
SUMMARY: The movie-theater chain’s CEO Adam Aron says the company will work on shoring up its balance sheet this year by trying to restructure expensive debt the company took on to survive.

TITLE: Law Firm Sullivan & Cromwell Taps New Leadership
SUMMARY: New York law firm Sullivan & Cromwell named litigator Robert Giuffra and corporate lawyer Scott Miller together as co-chairs, at a time when many large law firms are thriving.

TITLE: GM, VW Build Up Their Battery Supply Chains Amid EV Push
SUMMARY: Auto makers are trying to control more of the supply chain for electric vehicles, forging new partnerships with raw-materials producers and investing in facilities that make chemicals for batteries.

TITLE: India Hits Apple With Antitrust Investigation Over App-Store Practices
SUMMARY: The probe into how Apple runs its App Store adds to a series of global regulatory actions against U.S. tech companies. India’s watchdog was responding to allegations by a nonprofit group that a 30% fee on content sold through apps stifles competition.

TITLE: Apple Briefly Tops $3 Trillion Market Cap
SUMMARY: The iPhone maker’s shares closed below the milestone after a 41% jump since the beginning of 2021.

TITLE: The Elizabeth Holmes Verdict: Theranos Founder Is Guilty on Four of 11 Charges in Fraud Trial
SUMMARY: The verdict caps the downfall of the former Silicon Valley darling who claimed to revolutionize blood testing.

TITLE: AT&T and Verizon Agree to New Delay of 5G Rollout
SUMMARY: The telecom companies said they agreed to delay their rollout of a new 5G service for two weeks, reversing course after previously declining a request by U.S. transportation officials.

TITLE: Grammys Mull Postponement as Omicron Spread Disrupts Rebound in Entertainment
SUMMARY: The Recording Academy hadn’t yet reached a decision Monday morning, according to a person familiar with the matter.

TITLE: Starbucks Imposes Vaccine, Testing Requirements for U.S. Workers
SUMMARY: The coffee chain is one of the first large restaurant chains to take such a step ahead of potential federal Covid-19 vaccination mandates for large employers.

TITLE: David Bowie's Music Catalog Is Sold to Warner Chappell Music
SUMMARY: The deal, with an estimated value of $250 million, includes all of the singer’s studio albums.

TITLE: Job Openings on Track for New High Ahead of Omicron Wave
SUMMARY: There were 12 million job openings in the U.S. at the end of December, according to estimates. And the number of available workers continues to lag behind job postings.

TITLE: Fed Weighs Proposals for Eventual Reduction in Bond Holdings
SUMMARY: Shrinking the central bank’s $8.76 trillion asset portfolio offers another tool to tighten policy at a time of high inflation.

TITLE: Monthly Child-Tax-Credit Payments Cease, Ending Cushion for Family Budgets
SUMMARY: More than 30 million households started getting the child-tax payment in July, with parents using the money on essentials like groceries and stashing it as emergency savings. Unless Congress acts, that stream of cash is drying up.

TITLE: Toyota Overtakes GM as Best-Selling Auto Maker in U.S.
SUMMARY: The Japanese auto maker outsold GM by roughly 114,000 vehicles in 2021. Tesla and Hyundai gained U.S. market share as the semiconductor disruption affected companies differently.

TITLE: CDC Backs Pfizer-BioNTech Booster for Immunocompromised Children
SUMMARY: The CDC expanded its recommendation to get boosters to children 5 to 11 years with weakened immune systems. It also said people who got Pfizer’s vaccine should get a booster 5 months later, down from 6.

TITLE: Evergrande Is Told to Tear Down 39 Buildings on Man-Made Island
SUMMARY: The embattled property developer released data showing its financial stress had largely halted sales of new homes and said it had been ordered to tear down dozens of buildings on an extravagant man-made island in southern China.

TITLE: Workers Quit Jobs at a Record Level in November
SUMMARY: The number of times workers quit their jobs reached a fresh high in November, while job openings also remained elevated in a tight labor market.

TITLE: Ford Doubles Production Goal for F-150 Electric Pickup
SUMMARY: Ford said the increased production plans reflect high demand for the model. Shares of Ford recently rose about 9%.

TITLE: Find Covid-19 Home Tests Using Online Product Trackers
SUMMARY: Stock-monitoring platforms check inventory at various retailers and send users alerts if hot-ticket items become listed as available to purchase. But using these services is only half the battle.

TITLE: Come the Metaverse, Can Privacy Exist?
SUMMARY: In immersive worlds, new technologies will siphon up data at an increasingly granular level—a person’s gait, eye movements, emotions and more—putting far greater strain on existing safeguards.

TITLE: U.S. Prevails Over Canada in Dairy Dispute
SUMMARY: Canada has until Feb. 3 to change policies aimed at shielding its dairy industry from American competition, or the U.S. can proceed with tariffs, after a ruling published Tuesday.

TITLE: Tencent Sells Roughly $3 Billion in Shares of Singapore's Sea
SUMMARY: The Chinese internet giant retains a 19% stake in the e-commerce and videogame company, whose value topped $120 billion recently.

TITLE: Toyota Overtakes GM as Bestselling Auto Maker in U.S.
SUMMARY: The Japanese auto maker outsold GM for the first time last year as a global computer-chip shortage dealt an uneven blow to car businesses. Tesla and Hyundai gained U.S. market share.

TITLE: Walmart, Kroger Raise Prices of Covid-19 Test Kits
SUMMARY: The retailers’ price increases for BinaxNOW at-home rapid antigen tests come after the expiration of a deal with the White House to sell the kits for $14.

TITLE: Giorgio Armani Cancels Fashion Shows in Milan and Paris, Citing Covid-19
SUMMARY: The move by the Italian luxury fashion house comes as Omicron complicates plans for big events.

TITLE: How Biogen Fumbled Aduhelm, Its Once-Promising Alzheimer's Drug
SUMMARY: Early results were so impressive the company raced toward regulatory approval. But its decision to stop trials produced a therapy without proven efficacy that many patients aren’t taking; “potentially the worst drug launch of all time.”

TITLE: U.S. Prevails Over Canada in Dairy Dispute Under New Trade Deal
SUMMARY: Canada has until Feb. 3 to comply with the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement or the U.S. could begin the process of initiating tariffs or other countermeasures.

TITLE: In Elizabeth Holmes Trial, U.S. Gave Patients a Small Stage
SUMMARY: Prosecutors proved that the Theranos founder defrauded big-name investors about the capabilities of her blood-testing startup. But their charges involving lower-profile patients fell flat as minimal testimony, a clerical miscue and a missing database hurt patient cases.

TITLE: Blackstone-Backed Company to Buy Stake in Media Firm Co-Founded by Will Smith and Jada Pinkett-Smith
SUMMARY: A firm led by former Disney executives Kevin Mayer and Tom Staggs will pay about $60 million for more than 10% of Westbrook.

TITLE: Candle Media Buys Stake in Media Company Co-Founded by Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith
SUMMARY: A firm led by former Disney executives Kevin Mayer and Tom Staggs will pay about $60 million for more than 10% of Westbrook.

TITLE: The Sabbatical, a Power Move for the Burnout Era
SUMMARY: Some employees find the antidote to work stress and anxiety is a long company-sponsored break from their jobs.

TITLE: Fed's Neel Kashkari Now Sees Two 2022 Rate Rises Amid Inflation Surge
SUMMARY: The Minneapolis Fed leader also said he supported the central bank’s decision last month to accelerate the drawdown of its asset-buying stimulus effort.

TITLE: Factories Took a Small Step Back Toward Normal
SUMMARY: December’s slip in the ISM’s manufacturing index suggests that supply-chain problems are easing and that demand is beginning to be more easily met

TITLE: Bloomberg Media CEO Justin Smith Steps Down to Found News Startup
SUMMARY: Justin Smith sees opportunity to help address a crisis in trust among news consumers, and he has recruited Ben Smith of the New York Times to lead its future newsroom.

TITLE: Sony Looks to Sell Its Own Electric Vehicles
SUMMARY: The maker of PlayStation videogame consoles said it plans to create a car unit and explore entering the EV market.

TITLE: Tencent Sells Roughly $3 Billion in Shares of Singapore's Sea
SUMMARY: The Chinese internet giant retains a 19% stake in the e-commerce and videogame company, whose value topped $120 billion recently.

SUMMARY: PG&E power lines sparked last year’s massive wildfire, which exploded to become the second-largest in California history.

TITLE: WeWork Co-Founder Adam Neumann Is Becoming an Apartment Mogul
SUMMARY: Entities tied to the entrepreneur have bought majority stakes valued at a total of more than $1 billion in buildings in Southern cities.

SUMMARY: Deere said it has developed a fully autonomous tractor designed for large-scale farming and that it plans to sell the machine later this year.

SUMMARY: The telecom giant faces a busy year as it tries to complete a divorce with its entertainment business, ease investor concerns about its dividend and show that it can continue to woo new wireless customers.

SUMMARY: Western sportswear companies are losing ground in China to Anta amid a consumer boycott of foreign brands that take a stand on Xinjiang cotton.

SUMMARY: A top economist at J.P. Morgan says keeping the Federal Reserve’s books in the black could motivate the central bank to start an earlier and faster runoff of its balance sheet

SUMMARY: Chief information officers have emerged as key players in their companies’ sustainability programs, leading efforts to unload power-hungry computer-processing applications to the cloud and roll out tech aimed at energy optimization and waste reduction.

TITLE: Companies Expect Funding to Stay Cheap, Despite Rate Increases
SUMMARY: Many U.S. finance chiefs secured cheap funding in 2021 and anticipate similar conditions in 2022, although expected Fed rate increases are prompting companies to refinance debt coming due in the next few years.

SUMMARY: The country lacks the right policy tools to meet Xi Jinping’s vastly expanded goals as centralized power roils decision making.

SUMMARY: Valdis Dombrovskis, the European Union’s executive vice president, has won plaudits for his role in trans-Atlantic relations. President Biden was so pleased by the progress made at a summit over subsidies for plane makers that he joked he wanted to take Mr. Dombrovskis back to Washington to help get things done.

SUMMARY: The massive annual tech show—now taking place in Las Vegas and, thanks to Omicron, across the internet—is a fountain of important tech trends and far-out inventions to come.

SUMMARY: The GM-Ford rivalry enters the EV age, with Detroit’s two big auto makers taking different paths to rolling out new battery-powered trucks.

SUMMARY: Christopher Halpin will join the company later this month.

SUMMARY: A new, easy-to-remember 988 number is set to launch in July following the Federal Communications Commission’s approval in 2020.

SUMMARY: Talks between AT&T, Verizon and government officials went down to the wire as a deadline loomed.

SUMMARY: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes raised millions from venture capitalists, but Silicon Valley investors see little effects from her conviction in her criminal-fraud trial.

SUMMARY: Federal Reserve officials took steps last month that could allow for an interest-rate increase as soon as March.

SUMMARY: Banks such as JPMorgan and Goldman drew staff back into the office last year, but Covid-19’s resurgence is forcing them to bend to employees’ desire to work from a distance.

SUMMARY: Federal Reserve officials also are considering an earlier timetable for shrinking their $8.76 trillion bond portfolio.

SUMMARY: The move, which comes as the Omicron variant threatens to disrupt schooling, is one of the final steps in granting the adolescent cohort access to the additional shots.

SUMMARY: GM, Chrysler and Sony unveiled their future plans as the push toward battery-powered vehicles intensifies.

SUMMARY: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended Covid-19 boosters for 12- to 15-year-olds, making the doses available to the adolescents for the first time.

SUMMARY: Nexstar Media Group is among the suitors for CW Network, sources say.

SUMMARY: A flood of money means it is a great time for entrepreneurs, even with Elizabeth Holmes’s criminal conviction over her failed blood-testing company.

SUMMARY: Despite Omicron concerns, layoffs are estimated to edge down as employers struggle to find enough workers.

SUMMARY: Money-market conditions were very much on the minds of Federal Reserve officials at their meeting last month as they began debating how quickly to withdraw monetary policy stimulus for the U.S. economy.

SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis president says monetary policy “is in good position” to navigate current challenges.

SUMMARY: The Apple executive reached his 10th anniversary in a year when the iPhone maker saw record sales and profits.

SUMMARY: The assessments from regional Fed banks mark new attempts by economic policy makers to measure disruptions driven by the pandemic and shipping strains.

TITLE: Deliveroo, Probing Restaurant-Delivery Snags, Plans to Open Eatery
SUMMARY: The U.K.-based food-delivery company hopes running a single-location pizza parlor in London will help it better understand the restaurateurs using its platform.

TITLE: FedEx Warns of Shipping Delays as Omicron Hurts Staffing
SUMMARY: Severe winter storms around the country, including at the company’s Memphis, Tenn., hub, are also hurting deliveries.

TITLE: John Legend Sells His Music Catalog to KKR, BMG
SUMMARY: The deal for the songwriting catalog of John Legend—still an active songwriter, recording artist and performer—illustrates how red-hot the market for music investments has become.

TITLE: FAA Selects Airports for 5G Buffer Zones
SUMMARY: The zones aim to minimize flight disruptions by separating new wireless signals and aircraft.

TITLE: Employers, Investors Take Notice of AI Tools to Speed Job Recruitment
SUMMARY: Companies are looking for an edge in hiring through artificial intelligence and automation technology.

TITLE: U.S. to Spend $10 Billion to Boost Small Businesses
SUMMARY: The Treasury Department program aims to rev up business in disadvantaged communities and spur a broader economic recovery.

TITLE: Restaurants Seek Aid as Omicron Threatens Another Hard Winter
SUMMARY: Small operators are lobbying Congress for fresh funding as renewed Covid-19 restrictions, supply challenges and staffing shortages lead to continuing high costs and debt.

TITLE: Why Apple's iMessage Is Winning: Teens Dread the Green Text Bubble
SUMMARY: The iPhone maker cultivated iMessage as a must-have blue-bubble texting tool for teens. Android users trigger a just-a-little-less-cool green bubble: “Ew, that’s gross.”

TITLE: The End of Car Keys, Passwords and Fumbling With Your Phone at Checkout
SUMMARY: The ultra-wideband, or UWB, technology that powers Apple’s AirTags could reshape how we interact with devices—if companies can overcome privacy concerns and other hurdles.

TITLE: Facebook's Former Elections Boss Questions Social Media in Politics
SUMMARY: Katie Harbath, who says she left the company disillusioned, now pushes for more online guardrails.

TITLE: Meta Platforms' Head of Communications Leaves Company
SUMMARY: The departure of John Pinette comes after a WSJ series of articles pushed the company to put a tighter lid on internal research.

TITLE: The Crowd That Lifted Up Eventbrite's CEO
SUMMARY: Julia Hartz relied on the help of key advisers to steer the ticketing and events-management company through a severe crisis.

TITLE: Supply-Chain Issues Leave New Homes Without Garage Doors and Gutters
SUMMARY: Home builders blame bottlenecks for a huge backlog of uncompleted homes.

TITLE: Detroit Makes Its Move in Electric-Vehicle Race
SUMMARY: GM, Ford and Chrysler-owned Stellantis are looking to close the gap versus startups with initiatives such as new battery-powered pickups and electric-van sales to Amazon.

TITLE: Labs Limit Covid-19 Test Access as Demand Soars
SUMMARY: Triaging who is eligible for Covid-19 tests can help ensure that patients who need a test the most get results fast enough. But turning some people away from testing risks perpetuating the virus’s spread.

TITLE: Chinese Startups Failed to Catch Up to Advanced Chip Makers
SUMMARY: Companies that were launched to build semiconductors in China, including startups HSMC and QXIC, have failed despite hundreds of millions of dollars in investment and government support. Officials are sorting through the wreckage to see what went wrong.

TITLE: In the Race for Batteries, One Scientist Has Seen It All
SUMMARY: Susan Babinec is trying to put the U.S. in front again on batteries. She has been among leading U.S. battery scientists for more than 20 years and believes cutting-edge science will make that happen.

TITLE: Americans' Finances Got Stronger in the Pandemic---Confounding Early Fears
SUMMARY: Stimulus payments brought millions out of poverty and allowed them to clear debt, and households of all income levels built up savings. The stronger finances are expected to aid stability as normal spending and higher inflation return.

TITLE: Europe's Workers See Living Costs Rise, but Pay Isn't Keeping Pace
SUMMARY: Europe’s unemployment rate has fallen below its pre-pandemic level, but a surge in wages this year doesn’t seem likely even though higher inflation has weakened workers’ spending power, according to economists and officials.

TITLE: The Best Fitness Apps for Working Out at Home
SUMMARY: Working toward a fitness goal? For at-home workouts, pick a platform that has exercises for your fitness level, a variety of workout types and warm-ups to prevent injury.

TITLE: There Aren't Enough Chips---Why Are They So Hard to Make?
SUMMARY: An upstate New York factory shows the complicated process of turning silicon into a chip.

TITLE: PC Slowdown Sets a New Battleground for Chip Makers
SUMMARY: AMD needs to keep taking market share, while Intel can’t afford to lose it.
